Fields.DialogueText: EEEEEK!
Southampton, get a hold of yourself! What's wrong? And what are you doing on that chair?
Can't you see it, Captain? It's a rat! A massive one!

Fields.MenuText: Oh, for pity's sake, just kill it!
What?! Where?
Let it go. What's one rat going to do to us?

Fields.DialogueText: No! The only thing worse than a rat is a dead rat!
Captain! It's getting away!
Captain, it's never just one rat!
Calm down, it just ran off.
But to where, Captain? It could be anywhere on board! Filthy blighters... they get everywhere and ruin everything!
It could be worse. You could be a wooden ship.
Oh, ha ha! I'll have you know that the Black Death reached England through Southampton in exactly the way we just witnessed!
*ALARM*
Forget the rat, Southampton. I think we have more pressing business. The Morgana Disease has been sighted in these waters.
Oh, we've got disease all right...
Hilarious. I'll see you on the bridge.
@BATTLE
Yeah, I... wait. Do you actually remember the Black Death?
I'd rather not.
Are you... cleaning?
Of course, Captain! After our little rat adventure, I need to make sure I'm spotless and shipshape.
Shipshape?
Is something wrong, Captain?

Fields.MenuText: I don't know. I almost feel like I'm intruding on something private.
How do you expect to go over every inch of the ship... er... yourself?
Clean or dirty, we have to be ready for any enemy.

Fields.DialogueText: Really, Captain! You mustn't say such things. It's unbecoming!
A bit at a time, Captain. A light cruiser's work is never done!
Would you go into battle with holes in your socks? Throws you right off, it does!
You don't have to do this alone, you know. I'm sure you could get some of the crew to pitch in.
Oh, could I, Captain? We'd find the git in no time at all!
I'll see what I can do.
Wait... belay that, Captain, there's Morganas headed our way!
Aye-aye. I—Southampton, what are you doing?
Someone's got to wring out the mop, Captain! Don't want it getting moldy. Don't worry, I'll be up at the bridge in a tick!
... Right. I appreciate your attention to detail.
@BATTLE
Captain, what's the word from command on the North Sea?
It's swarming with Morganas. We're effectively cut off from Iceland and the rest of the mainland until we can stabilize British waters.
Don't need to tell me twice. Even here I can feel their presence. So much darkness in one place... it isn't right.
You Belles have keen senses.
I can't really explain it. Belles and Morganas are natural enemies, but we're... well, drawn to each other somehow. I think they seek us out in the same way.
We're closing on one now. Are you ready?
As I'll ever be. Ugh... that rat is still somewhere on deck!
Ignore it. With any luck it'll be shellshocked. Action stations!
@BATTLE
Ow... that Morgana really didn't go quietly.
Do they ever? She—My God! Southampton, what is that?
Oh, this? Nothing major.
You've got a bruise across half your arm! Damage report, now!
A dud shell stuck in the hull, I'll wager. Not to worry. I'll sort it!
Where are you going? Southampton!
Ah, that did it!
You fixed it yourself?
Took some cutting, but it fell right out. Nothing a quick patch job won't fix!

Fields.MenuText: We should head back to port. I'm not taking any chances with hull damage like this.
Are you... feeling all right?
You work fast. How do you just shrug these things off?

Fields.DialogueText: Just to pick up replacement armor plating. We're patching up at sea!
Never better. What doesn't kill me only makes me stronger, after all!
It takes more than a shell to put me out of action. I reckon a shot to the pom-pom magazine wouldn't do more than bloody my nose!
Your call...
Right, lads, on to the next one!
Southampton, what are you doing in the crew's quarters?
I'm so glad you asked! I simply had to have the crew clean their quarters. Part of the ship, part of me, after all. And cleanliness begins in the home, you know.
I suppose it does. Any word on the rat?
Ugh, don't remind me! None of the crew have seen it. And the only thing worse than seeing a rat is not seeing one you know is there...
What about their other duties?
Worked up rotating shifts for them, Captain! Not a minute goes by without someone doing the tidying.

Fields.MenuText: Sounds like you've got things under control, Southampton. Don't have them do anything I wouldn't.
Is all this really necessary for hunting the Morganas?
Just don't let it interfere with your work. Our job is to keep the seas safe.

Fields.DialogueText: Thank you, Captain, but that reminds me—your quarters are next on the list!
Having a comfy, cozy place to rest certainly can't hurt. The better the prospect of a nap, the harder you fight for it.
Understood. I'll keep my eyes open.
In any case, we're close to the rendezvous point now. That convoy has to make it to the Faroes intact.
Are we expecting trouble?
Always. Asphyxiation has been sighted in these waters, and she's taken a liking to our cargo vessels.
I'll keep my eyes open, Captain... wait! Captain, we need to get to the bridge now!
Already? Good senses, Southampton.
@BATTLE
How are they taking it?
Oh, they love the idea! All it took was a little chat and some tea for them to come around. There'll be no Southampton Mutiny today!
Watch where you're swinging those scissors!
Oh, blimey, Captain, I didn't see you there!
No, I should have said something. What's all this on the deck?
Bit of steel, bit of armour... thought I'd spruce up the hull. It was looking dodgy after that last scrap of ours.
In the middle of contested waters?
We've driven the Morganas off for now. I'll say this for them: they know when they're done over.

Fields.MenuText: I'd rather you left nonessential maintenance for in port. We don't know what we might run into out here.
One less thing for the sailors to worry about.
How long will this take?

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, come off it! Anything comes our way, we give it a kicking and patch up anyway! I'd expect nothing less of my complement.
They're good kids, your sailors, but some things you need an extra-careful touch for.
Long enough to get the job done and done right. Some of our lot are on the case with me.
Speaking of, I wanted to thank you for what you've done with the crew. Every inspection has turned up spotless since you had them clean.
It's all about good habits, Captain! You don't really appreciate a good job until you've done it yourself, and then you want to do it better.
You've got a good work ethic, Southampton.
Just doing my due diligence. If she's worth sailing, she's worth sailing good as new!
Just be careful with those scissors, will you?
Aye-aye, Captain, though I've never met a wound I couldn't sew up!
Let's keep it that way. It looks like some Morganas smell blood.
@BATTLE
Does it hurt?
Does what hurt?
When you're hit in battle. You can feel the smallest things in your structure—
—Like that rat. Still haven't found him, have we?
So why wouldn't it hurt when you come under fire?
Hmm... have you ever broken a bone, Captain?
Sure. Why?
Imagine you break your arm, or it's mangled somehow, but you can still use it. It moves all right, but it hurts like bloody hell.
That's how a Belle feels when a torpedo breaches her hull.
That can't be pleasant.
Maybe not, but it lights a fire under us to stay in top condition. We're only as good as we treat ourselves, you know.
We're about to engage Mistrust. Let's light a fire under her, shall we?
Couldn't agree more!
@BATTLE
Blast! She's getting away.
This isn't good. She's limping, but we can't risk her running aground. The further they are from land, the better.
I could kick some extra speed out of my engines, but we're running well ragged after a ruck like that.

Fields.MenuText: She's out of our range. Damn it, she's just going to come back stronger!
I'll call this one in. We can get a squadron of bombers to see if we can't finish her off.
We've driven her off. Let's alert Her Majesty's Coastguard and keep them in the loop.

Fields.DialogueText: Reminds me of me. We'll be ready when she does!
If you say so. Hate to leave a job unfinished, even if we're a bit perforated.
Are you sure, Captain? We got into this mess, we should be the ones to sort it.
We've got to do what's best for us, and this is it.
Aye-aye. Now, where did I put those extra sheets of steel...
*sniff* Bother...
Are you feeling all right, Southampton? You look... sick, somehow. Is that possible?
Just a chill, Captain. I don't have quite the armor of my Edinburgh-class sisters. The weather gets to me a bit easier.
I didn't know Belles could get colds.
The same way we feel structural damage. It'll pass as I get acclimated.

Fields.MenuText: Is there anything you can do in the meantime?

Fields.DialogueText: Throw tea at the problem until it goes away, I suppose. Got to warm up somehow...
I've received reports of Morganas intercepting our convoy today. Will that help?
ACHOO! Captain, if this doesn't, nothing will.
@BATTLE
Ah, nothing like a good scrap to clear the sinuses!
You sound better already.
Just had to rev the engines and fire a few shots. Battle really can be therapeutic, can't it?
Perhaps it can. I still wouldn't say no to that cup of tea, though.
Help yourself to mine, Captain. I've been working on this Earl Grey for the whole tour...

Fields.MenuText: So what happens if you go somewhere hot?

Fields.DialogueText: Swallow my pride and ice down my tea, I suppose. I'd almost rather take the sniffles.

Fields.MenuText: Belles can't get worse diseases, can they?

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, don't you worry about that! It's all to do with my outside, nothing to do with my inside. A plague could knock you all off your feet and I'd be standing by with towels and bedpans.
Er... please don't catch a plague?
Captain, what's the matter? You look like you've lost something.
It's my journal, Southampton. I set it down in the mess hall, and now it's missing.
It's not missing, Captain. It's exactly where it should be! Top drawer, left side, next to the paper clips.
... How and why do you know that?
I've been doing some tidying, Captain. You've got to have your things in order if you want to be fighting fit!
Looks like we're getting a Morgana alert. We're going to need to talk about your tidying when all is said and done.
Aye-aye!
@BATTLE
And... there we have it!
Southampton... my quarters are...
Much cleaner than they were this morning, no?
When did you have the time to do this?
Here and there while you were out. You mentioned that it was getting a bit cluttered in here, so I took some liberties!
Especially with the decor.
Oh, no, are the doilies too much? I had some lying around that I made, just sitting there, really...

Fields.MenuText: I appreciate the gesture, but the captain's quarters are the captain's quarters. No trespassing and no doilies.
Actually, they do brighten up the room. Thank you, Southampton.
If I were you I'd be more concerned with the war we're fighting.

Fields.DialogueText: Roger that. I'll be sure to ask next time!
Really? Brilliant! I picked out my best, too—it even matches the antimacassar!
Understood, Captain. I was only trying to help...
Next time...? Well, all right. See that you do.
I must be the only captain with a ship that decorates herself.
Let me be the judge of what counts as help.
Maybe the antimacassar was too much after all...
Think of me as a home away from home!
With sketches and swatches! You ought to be included in these decisions, after all.
*ALARM*
Southampton, I've got good news and bad news.
Let's have the good news first.
His Majesty's Coastguard reports that the mass of North Atlantic Morgana forces seem to be pulling away from Great Britain for now.
Captain, that's excellent! I knew they wouldn't stick around.
Well, that's not quite the case. They found Mistrust.
The one that got away?
She gave out just north of Scotland and ran aground on an island.
Which one?
Fair Isle. Mostly uninhabited, but Chain Home Low has an interest in a site called Ward Hill. Until the wreck is cleared, North Sea radar operations are compromised.
But that would leave a massive hole in our defenses!
You've seen firsthand what a damaged Morgana is capable of. It's unpredictable, and we can't chance losing men without knowing the score.
Well, what are we waiting for? Let's go find her!

Fields.MenuText: Agreed. I'll alert the rest of the squadron that we're setting a course for Fair Isle.
I don't like this. She'd recognize us, and we don't want to risk her having adapted to our tactics.
This is the RAF's fight too. I'll get them and the Coastguard to coordinate with us on this.

Fields.DialogueText: You know I've never met a wound I couldn't sew up. Let's set sail!
Well, I hate leaving a job unfinished. Sounds like we'll just need to be flexible.
Have them keep us posted, won't you?
We have our objective. Let's complete it.
Right, we'll... Captain! Morganas are closing, and fast!
Good instinct, Southampton! Action stations!
@BATTLE
What do you know about Fair Isle?
Enough, I suppose. I was actually laid down in Clydebank, so I know a fair bit about Scotland and England both.
Small, mostly crofters and knitters... Oh, that reminds me!
What is it?
They've got a knitting style I've been meaning to try for ages! Sort of a regular knit stitch, but you don't have to purl... or something. But it looks gorgeous!
We'll see what happens when we get there. Keep your eyes open, we don't know what's in store for us.
Wait, Captain... do you see that? On the beach?
It's not on the beach, it's in front of it... and getting closer!
Captain! I recognize her! Mistrust! Action stations!
Adjust course and slow, Southampton. This could get ugly.
@BATTLE
Damage report.
Knackered, Captain... but not out.
That's the spirit. How could she have recovered so quickly?
The Morganas aren't so different from us Belles, I reckon. Give them time and the pieces to put themselves back together, and they're up and at you all over again.
But this is just a farming island. Where are the pieces?
I don't know. Odds are we don't want to know, either.

Fields.MenuText: Well, I do. I'm sending an away team to investigate the settlement.
Perhaps you're right. Mistrust is gone now, and that's all that matters.
What makes you say that?

Fields.DialogueText: Captain, please don't! Keep them with me and we'll have the Coastguard take care of it.
We've done our duty. We can call this one in.
Call it an instinct, Captain. Whatever Mistrust did... it wasn't good for Fair Isle.
I trust you, but one way or another we're going to find out.
Captain, you're looking unwell.
I'm sorry to hear that. I'm functional, though.
Is there anything I can do for you?

Fields.MenuText: Just a moment, Southampton. I need to process this.
Could you put a kettle on? We need to talk.
All those islanders... they were just...

Fields.DialogueText: It's about Fair Isle, isn't it? What happened to it? What happened to them?
Always, Captain. A spot of tea helps the bad news go down.
I reckon I'd better put on some tea for this.
We were right about Mistrust. She was using the island somehow to repair. And not just the buildings... the people...
They'd been captured?
Our scouts told us differently. They saw people walking out to the wreck with tools, bricks, anything they could carry. It was like they were being controlled.
Ugh, that's sickening. But does that mean we—
I think now we know where Mistrust got her crew.
Oh, God... we fought her, Captain... her and everyone aboard!
We can't worry about that now. The people on that ship likely can't be saved.
We don't know that! You don't know that!
Southampton, listen to me! We can't hesitate for an instant if our mission is in danger! We can't let our crew meet the same fate as Mistrust's. Nor anyone else.
We'd need to keep the Morganas from making landfall in the first place!
We've done all we can do. Once radar coverage is complete, Scotland will be considerably more secure. Fair Isle was the last salient in our defenses.
No matter where we end up, Captain, I'm not letting this happen again.
That's the Morgana alert. Here's your chance.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Orders are in. We're headed to Iceland on the next patrol.
Fair Isle is secure?
Yes. And they've begun a partial evacuation of the other Shetland Islands, just to be safe. We've done all we can there.
There's always someone who could use our help. I'll be glad to get back out there.
What is that you're taking apart?
One of the away team brought it to me. It's a jumper in the Fair Isle style I mentioned. There's no one left to teach me the knitting, but if I undo it I might be able to learn.

Fields.MenuText: Do you often take souvenirs?
I never thought of that. You just work backwards to get the technique?
What do you plan on doing with it?

Fields.DialogueText: I'm not much of a traveler. I just help others get from A to B. It's nice to have a memento.
Sometimes that's the best way to look at things. Start with the finish and then find the thread back to the beginning.
Make more jumpers. Blankets. Anything, really. It's my way of keeping Fair Isle alive.
This is a rough business. It's nice to see someone take time for the small things.
If you can't share the small things, what's the point of the big things?
Do you suppose you could make some of these for the crew?
That was my aim, once I... oh, bugger!
What?
There's another Morgana group coming. They'll make me lose my place!
Big things, Southampton. Big things.
@BATTLE
And we're off. Next stop - Reykjavik.
It's supposed to be beautiful there! I hear the Vikings named it Iceland just to discourage others from taking it.
Not exactly. One of them just named it that after ice floes he saw in a harbor.
Oh. Is that all?
Well, that and all his cattle had died in the winter. He was frustrated, I suppose.
You learn something new every day. How many things are a certain way just because someone was angry?

Fields.MenuText: You wouldn't believe.
That's just the way humans can be.
I'm sure there's more to it than that.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm sure I wouldn't. I can try, though.
But it's not the way you have to be.
So much more. That's why I love hearing about your world.
What do you mean?
Well, I'm a Belle. And I know plenty about my namesake, and my country, and our king. But these things change, and I think learning how and why is part of loving them.
I... hadn't really thought about it that way.
Maybe if more people did, they wouldn't be so angry.
Let's hold off on the philosophy for now. We've had word that Destruction is here to greet us.
Well, that's ominous.
More for her than for us.
@BATTLE
This is all amazing! I've always wanted to go to Iceland.
You've never been abroad?
Never been deployed outside of home waters! But my sisters and I go where we're needed. We could be sent to Malta, or New York... even Hong Kong!
I never took you for a traveler.
Well, not really. I prefer to keep my home in order. Before the Morganas they wanted me to patrol the Channel, but I suppose that's changed, hasn't it?
I think the Germans have more things to worry about than invading Britain now.
Don't even joke about that, Captain! The less said about those U-boat fiends, the better, I say.
Germans?
Three words, Captain: unrestricted submarine warfare. No ship was safe during the Great War. Even civilians were fair targets... bloody reprehensible. I've never forgiven it.

Fields.MenuText: I see I've touched a nerve.
It doesn't bother you that the Royal Family's descended from Germans?
What about the German Belles?

Fields.DialogueText: I defend cargo ships for a living, Captain. Nobody touches them and gets away with it.
And they had the good sense to change their name! The Windsors left behind that Saxe-Coburg-Gotha nonsense during the Great War, thank you very much!
Well, they can sink all the Morganas they want. But they'd better stay out of my way.
And German crew here? Part of the arrangement is an increased international presence, after all.
My crew are my family, Captain. That's all there is to it.
... I'm trying, anyway.
I see. Forget I brought it up.
No, I'm sorry, Captain. Belles are... well, we're keen on our origins. We hold grudges because our countries do. Some of the French ones still give me the cold shoulder!
Well, don't let it interfere with the mission. Morganas don't care who they shoot at.
Understood, Captain. Today, we are all Icelandic.
@BATTLE
What do you call those little bay things again?
You mean fjords?
Yes, fjords! Such a funny word, but so beautiful. I wish I could walk up there...
But Belles can't go far from their ships, can they?
Nature of the beast, really. Something for the crew to do on shore leave, however!
That certainly explains the jumpers and mittens I've been seeing them wear lately.
It took some doing, Captain, but I'm getting the hang of this Fair Isle knitting! Would you like to try it?

Fields.MenuText: I've never really been one for knitting.
Maybe one day, if I've got some time away from the war.
Can you show me how?

Fields.DialogueText: Your loss, Captain! It's dead useful when you're in need of something warm and comfy.
Oh, come on! Minute to learn, lifetime to master and all that.
I'd love to! Come on, sit down and I'll teach you the needlework.
Even if it's just a basic whip stitch, everyone needs to know how to work with clothing.
You're certainly not wrong. It'd definitely keep the crew in uniforms longer.
Oh, bollocks! The Morganas are coming, Captain. And just when I was wrapping up this pattern.
@BATTLE
You know, talking of uniforms, I've noticed there's quite a few different ones among the crew.
There's not exactly an official INPF uniform yet. It hasn't been deemed a high priority.
Well, that simply won't do. I'm sure with some time and enough fabric I could...
*ALARM*
Southampton, Morganas are harassing the latest convoy! Action stations!
On my way, Captain! No mercy for those cargo bullies!
@BATTLE
Southampton, you've been quiet since that last battle with Calamity. What's the matter?
You were there when we closed on her, Captain. You saw her crew. I'd recognize that clothing anywhere. Fair Isle.

Fields.MenuText: You can tell the technique from that far off?
You mean there were other islanders on that ship?
But Mistrust was the only one who attacked them, wasn't she?

Fields.DialogueText: That's not important, Captain. They're mocking us. Something isn't right.
I don't know, but she was trying to tell us something. I can't shake the feeling.
Maybe. We don't know how many other Morganas came near the island.
I can't be sure how, but this has to be a message of some sort.
In some kind of knitting code?
Think it out, Captain! There wasn't a single person alive on that island when we got there. And I thought they were all with Mistrust.
You said Belles and Morganas aren't so different. Maybe they worked backward just like you did.
But that would mean...
We can't give them an inch. Everything they take they'll use against us.
... Captain. Don't you ever get taken by one of those things.
Nor you. We can't afford to give them our best.
The crew's looking spiffy lately.
I thought their uniforms could do with some sprucing up. What do you think of epaulettes?
Rank restricted.
Bollocks. Back to the drawing board. I wanted to work up some prototypes just for my crew before showing them off to Command.
Southampton—
... Or not. Captain, we've sighted Morganas!
I appreciate the warning. Listen, no matter what you see... you fire. All right?
I'll do what I can.
@BATTLE
Why would anyone go over to the Morganas? What power could possess them to do it?
Captain, do you know about the Southampton Mutiny?
I remember you mentioning it. 1919, was it?
Right. Five thousand British soldiers land in port thinking they're going home. But the lot are getting redeployed to France instead. So they take over the docks and refuse to leave.

Fields.MenuText: What did they think that would solve?

Fields.DialogueText: They weren't mutinying because they wanted to do harm, Captain. They'd been lied to. They were tired.
But what do the Morganas—
You haven't heard them speak, Captain.
What do they say?
Awful things. The sort of stuff makes you think there's nothing worth living for. We Belles know it's bollocks, but Morganas have this way of getting in you humans' heads...
Maybe they use those thoughts to overwhelm people, and brainwash them into doing their bidding.
It's a scary thought.
It is, indeed. All the more reason for us to stick together. If you're ever doubt yourself, you come to me.
Same to you. That's what I'm here for.

Fields.MenuText: I thought the war was over by that time.
Did it work?

Fields.DialogueText: So did they.
Well, the higher-ups were lenient, mostly. Still sent them to France, though.
Captain, do you have a moment?
Always, Southampton. What can I do for you?
I wanted your opinion on something. I think... I think we can rehabilitate one of the Morganas' crew.

Fields.MenuText: I think you may be setting yourself up for disappointment. There have been attempts. They... didn't usually go well.
What makes you say that?
Let's go back to the epaulettes...

Fields.DialogueText: Maybe I am. Maybe nobody has. But we have to try. We have to know.
If otherwise normal people can be brainwashed to serve evil... can't they be unbrainwashed to come back to good?
My mind's on other things, Captain, but I'll hold you to that.
Even if we could bring someone back from a Morgana crew, is it worth the risk for one person?
If we're not willing to take risks for our own, what reason do they have to do the same for us? You have to trust me, Captain.
Our mission is to clear the Norwegian Sea. Endanger us and we endanger Iceland.
Think of what they could teach us! Nobody has ever lived to tell about what goes on aboard a Morgana. If we save one, we could save so many more!
I'll tell you what. You come up with a way to get someone off a Morgana safely, and I'll give you whatever you need to do it. But you're responsible for the operation.
Already working up a plan, Captain! You won't regret it.
Action stations, Southampton. We're not far from the Morganas.
@BATTLE
Knitting again?
Always, Captain, though not for our crew. You could call it a gift for the Morganas.
Is... is that a rope?
The crew was kind enough to scrounge up some nylon for me. One of the Americans taught me about roping cattle. How different can this be?

Fields.MenuText: Careful with them. They're still human.
Now you're starting to sound like a Morgana.
Quite a bit, actually.

Fields.DialogueText: They've been through worse. They can take a tumble into the ocean.
Someone said know your enemy, and I'm willing to believe them.
Oh, hush. Got to be adaptable in this business, haven't you?
It's... patterned? Why does it look like a sweater?
Fair Isle, Captain. The Morganas can consider it a gift.
We shouldn't be more than a couple of hours from them. Will you be ready in time?
Sotonians are born ready.
@BATTLE
How's our guest doing?
Locked in the brig.

Fields.MenuText: Not very hospitable.

Fields.DialogueText: I put a rug in there to brighten things up. He still isn't taking to the tea, though. I'm going to try and talk to him today.
Be careful. Is he violent?
Oddly, no. That's what worries me. It's like he's waiting for something.
Maybe... do you hear that?
Is he... screaming?
Southampton, are we alone out here?
No, Captain! The Morganas are about to be right on top of us!
I suppose we owe our new friend some thanks.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: We'd be safer without him there.
Is he safe?

Fields.DialogueText: If he's dangerous to anyone, Captain, it's to himself. I'm keeping a close eye on him.
As safe as he can be. I'm not going to restrain him unless he gets... funny.
You look like you've had better days.
I've solved some mysteries, Captain.
What did you learn?
Less than I would have liked to know and more of what I didn't want to.
By which you mean...?
Remember the rat we never found?
You had the crew combing the ship for weeks. How could I forget?
The Morgana crewman found it.
It got into his cell?
Yes. He thought it was delicious.

Fields.MenuText: What does that mean for rehabilitating him?
What's he doing now?
Rats.

Fields.DialogueText: We're no closer than we were before. He's not responding to anything I do or say.
He was just... sitting there. Turning occasionally to face true north. Apparently he was the Morgana's navigator.
You're not being funny.
This is frustrating, Captain. He's not like any person I've ever seen. Nothing gets through to him.
You've done all you can do, Southampton. It may be time to call this thing off.
I'm not ready to do that, Captain! There has to be a way to bring him back!
And what if there isn't? What if we can't save everyone?
I'm a Belle, Captain. It's what I was born for.
There he goes again. Action stations.
@BATTLE
I'm getting sick of that screaming, Captain. It's putting me right off my tea.
You're not even talking to him anymore.
What's the point? At this stage he's a better alarm system than I am. May as well use that.
Try not to dwell on it. We're closing on Dismay now.
@BATTLE
Captain... you saw what I saw, didn't you?
Our guest? I saw. Who left his cell unlocked?
I had the crew watching him in shifts. We all slip up from time to time.

Fields.MenuText: Slip up? There was an insane prisoner aboard and at large!
And yet nothing came of it.
That's an understatement.

Fields.DialogueText: Nobody knows that better than the man guarding him.
No injuries. No damage. Nothing.
Even so, that's all it was.
And that's what worries me. I saw him after the battle, when Dismay was fleeing. He was standing on my starboard side, watching her flee. Then he just... jumped.
I don't know what to say.
Neither did I.
Captain. You wanted to see me?
How do you take your tea?
Excuse me?
How do you take your tea?
Teaspoon of honey.
That's what I thought. Sit down.
Captain, I know what you're going to say. It wasn't my fault, but I don't care.
What do you mean?
The crew were never in any danger, but... I don't understand. The Morgana sailor just wouldn't budge. Why?

Fields.MenuText: I can't answer that.
Sometimes when you're in enough pain, you lose touch with everything else.
Why do we need to know? It's over now.

Fields.DialogueText: That's exactly what bothers me.
I can't imagine that. I don't want to.
Because I don't want to abandon him! I don't want to abandon anyone!
I don't know how else to put it. Some things you just can't recover from. Some things you just can't prevent. War is like that.
Captain, I'm a light cruiser. I can't accept that. I was built to protect people, protect their shipping. I'm—
You're not just a light cruiser, Southampton. You're compassionate, you're kind, you're selfless to a fault. It's not what you are, it's who you are.
You can't just—
No other crew can say that their ship makes them new clothes. You're special, Southampton. You don't need to work miracles.
We'll have to table this, Captain. We're entering Morgana waters.
Your tea's getting cold.
Let it.
@BATTLE
Tea, Captain?
Of course. You've been scarce lately.
Just keeping busy, Captain. Helps me keep things in perspective.
How do you mean?
It's interesting, now that I think about it. Why do you think the prisoner didn't harm the crew?
He was certainly happy to harm the rat.
But it wasn't for its own sake. I still think he was just hungry.
Always with the benefit of the doubt, eh?
That's the only way I like to doubt.
So what does this all mean?
I want to believe the Morgana crews aren't interested in hurting us. They're just lost.

Fields.MenuText: So there may be a way to find them again.
Lost, or broken?
Why is this so important to you? Aren't we putting them out of their misery?

Fields.DialogueText: I have to believe there is. Everyone has someone to defend them, no matter where they are.
Either way, I still believe they can be fixed.
Because why put someone out of their misery if you can get them to stop being miserable?
Misery loves company.
I don't think you and I agree on what that means. I'll just have to prove you wrong.
I hope you do.
Hey, maybe one day we'll find a Morgana called Misery and you can sink her to illustrate the point.
And maybe one day we'll finish a pot of tea.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Where to next, Captain?
We've done all we can do with Iceland. Norway's our next objective.
Oh! That reminds me... take this.
Southampton, I don't know what to say. Thank you.
It's cold where we're going, Captain. I couldn't decide whether you needed socks, a jumper, a scarf... so I just made two of everything.
This knitting... this is Fair Isle, isn't it?
Think of it as a reminder, Captain. No matter where you are, no matter how hopeless it seems, there's always something worth saving.

Fields.MenuText: I'll keep that in mind. I want to believe you.

Fields.DialogueText: You don't have to. That takes all the fun out of convincing you.
We're not far from Utsira. Convince the Morganas and you'll be well on your way.
Whatever it takes.

Fields.MenuText: I never assumed I'd be so thankful to have a friend constantly sewing things for other people... but I am.
I'll need to put these away for safekeeping. If Southampton made them... then they really are special.

Fields.DialogueText: Ooh, I've always wanted to go there! All those... fjords, that's the word. It'll be so pretty I might forget how cold it gets.

Fields.MenuText: We can't save everyone, Southampton. Especially not at the cost of the mission.

Fields.DialogueText: That's just something you'll never convince me of, Captain. But I trust your judgment.

Fields.MenuText: I'll be sure to wear it when the going gets tough.

Fields.DialogueText: Appreciate it, Captain. Nothing like a friend by your side to convince you of the impossible.
